SubTopics: Analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text, including how the major sections and text features (e.g., headings) contribute to the whole and to the development of the ideas.
Content: What is the ğ— ğ—¢ğ—¦ğ—§ ğ—Ÿğ—œğ—ğ—˜ğ—Ÿğ—¬ reason the author included paragraph 1 of â€œLucy Larcom and Harriet Hansonâ€?

A.Choice: to illustrate that many mill workers came from selfish families

B.Choice: to demonstrate that many mill workers had negative attitudes

C.Choice: to emphasize that many mill workers had similar experiences

D.Choice: to highlight that many mill workers lived with supportive roommates

SubTopics: Determine a text's central idea(s) and analyze its/their development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of a text.
Content: Which sentence from â€œLucy Larcom and Harriet Hansonâ€ ğ—•ğ—˜ğ—¦ğ—§ shows Lucy's unwillingness to give in to the difficulties of life in the mill?

A.Choice: â€œStill, even as a little child, she always expected that she'd wind up in the mill.â€ (paragraph 3)

B.Choice: â€œBut, for the sake of the family, Lucy put aside her dreams...â€ (paragraph 4)

C.Choice: â€œ'I defied the machinery to make me its slave,' ...â€ (paragraph 6)

D.Choice: â€œ'The buzzing and hissing whizzing of pulleys and rollers and spindles and flyers often grew tiresome.'â€ (paragraph 6)

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: Read the sentences from paragraph 7 of â€œLucy Larcom and Harriet Hansonâ€ in the box.
:box:The little ones often fell asleep standing up. But the machines never slept.
What is the ğ— ğ—”ğ—œğ—¡ effect of the author's use of personification?

A.Choice: It suggests competition between the child workers and the machines.

B.Choice: It emphasizes a contrast between the child workers and the machines.

C.Choice: It demonstrates the advantages that the child workers had over the machines.

D.Choice: It shows that child workers were important to the proper functioning of the machines.

SubTopics: Analyze the interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in a text (e.g., how ideas influence individuals or events, or how individuals influence ideas or events).
Content: In â€œLucy Larcom and Harriet Hanson,â€ why did the company take the boardinghouse away from Harriet's mother?

A.Choice: Harriet had not paid a fine to the agent.

B.Choice: Harriet's mother had not let Harriet complete her work.

C.Choice: Harriet had not allowed the older girls to leave for the day.

D.Choice: Harriet's mother had not stopped Harriet from taking action.

SubTopics: Analyze the interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in a text (e.g., how ideas influence individuals or events, or how individuals influence ideas or events).
Content: Based on â€œLucy Larcom and Harriet Hanson,â€ how was Harriet's life ğ— ğ—¢ğ—¦ğ—§ğ—Ÿğ—¬ affected by her actions?

A.Choice: She was fired by the mill owners.

B.Choice: She decided to fight for equality for others.

C.Choice: She was determined to demand more money in future jobs.

D.Choice: She was motivated by her experience to start her own business.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 7 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.

Content: What does the word trial mean as it is used in paragraph 8 of Lyddie?

SubTopics: Analyze how aspects of a literary work's structure contribute to its meaning or style (e.g., the effect of repetition in an epic, flashback in a novel, soliloquy in a drama).
Content: Read the description from paragraph 9 of Lyddie in the box.

:box:Now that she thought of it, she could hardly breathe, the air was so laden with moisture and debris. She snatched a moment to run to the window. She had to get air, but the window was nailed shut against the April morning. She leaned her forehead against it; even the glass seemed hot.
What is the ğ— ğ—”ğ—œğ—¡ purpose of the description?

C.Choice: to illustrate how a character resolves a conflict

D.Choice: to show the impact of the setting on a character

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what a text states explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text, quoting or paraphrasing as appropriate.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 15 of Lyddie in the box.
:box:Yesterday seemed years in the past.
Based on the passage, what does the sentence ğ— ğ—”ğ—œğ—¡ğ—Ÿğ—¬ suggest about Lyddie?

A.Choice: She is impressed by the machinery at the mill.

B.Choice: She realizes her life has changed significantly.

C.Choice: She misses her family more than she expected.

D.Choice: She is unable to remember working on the farm.

Topics: Informational Text - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient to support the claims.

Content: What does the author of â€œLucy Larcom and Harriet Hansonâ€ ğ— ğ—”ğ—œğ—¡ğ—Ÿğ—¬ suggest about working in the mills?

A.Choice: It taught the workers to be dependable.

B.Choice: It was a miserable experience for the workers.

C.Choice: It was an easy way for the workers to earn money.

D.Choice: It helped the workers learn skills they could use on their farms.

Content: Which sentence from Lyddie ğ— ğ—”ğ—œğ—¡ğ—Ÿğ—¬ supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: â€œFrom every direction, Lyddie could hear the shrill voices of girls calling to one another, even singing.â€ (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: â€œLyddie's first full day as a factory girl had begun.â€ (paragraph 7)

C.Choice: â€œOr perhaps the tears were caused by the swirling dust and lint.â€ (paragraph 8)

D.Choice: â€œShe pointed to the stalled loom and the broken warp thread that must be tied.â€ (paragraph 10)

SubTopics: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking; retain and further develop language skills learned in previous grades.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.

Write informative/explanatory texts (e.g., essays, oral reports, biographical feature articles) to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.
Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.
Content:
:ibox:For this question, you will write an essay based on the passage(s). Your writing should:

â€¢ Present and develop a central idea.

â€¢ Provide evidence and/or details from the passage(s).

â€¢ Use correct grammar, spelling, and punctuation.

Write an essay identifying a central idea of ğ—•ğ—¢ğ—§ğ—› â€œLucy Larcom and Harriet Hansonâ€ and Lyddie, and explain how it is developed throughout each text. Be sure to use information from ğ—•ğ—¢ğ—§ğ—› the article and the passage to develop your essay.
